title: SB 971
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The First Validating Act of 2016, also known as Section 1, defines "public body" to include various state departments, agencies, and entities like air pollution control districts and airport districts. Various districts and authorities in California are included in the definition of "public body," such as bridge and highway districts, water districts, pest control districts, maintenance districts, college districts, development commissions, facilities districts, rehabilitation districts, services districts, conservancy districts, education boards, drainage districts, flood control districts, library systems, sanitation districts, service areas, transportation commissions, water agencies, water authorities, and waterworks districts. Various districts and authorities in California are considered part of the "public body," including county water authorities, water districts, drainage districts, fire protection districts, harbor districts, highway districts, housing authorities, and irrigation districts, among others. Various types of districts and authorities in California are considered part of the "public body," including integrated financing districts, irrigation districts, joint highway districts, levee districts, library districts, local agency formation commissions, local health care districts, local hospital districts, and more. Various types of districts and authorities in California fall under the "public body," including property and business improvement areas, protection districts, public utility districts, rapid transit districts, and more. Various types of districts and authorities in California, such as storm water districts, toll tunnel authorities, transit development boards, and water agencies, are considered "public bodies." However, certain entities like community redevelopment agencies are excluded from this classification. The term "public body" includes the successor agencies to the Redevelopment Agency of the City and County of San Francisco and other successor agencies for the purpose of issuing bonds or incurring indebtedness as specified in the Health and Safety Code. The term "Bonds" refers to all forms of indebtedness incurred by a public body for public purposes. "Hereafter" denotes any time after the effective date of this act, while "Heretofore" refers to any time before that date. "Now" signifies the effective date of this act. SEC. 3 declares all public bodies previously organized under any law to be legally functioning. SEC. 4 confirms the boundaries of public bodies as previously established. SEC. 5 validates the legality of public body boundaries shown on maps or plats used by the assessor. SEC. 5 confirms and validates all acts and proceedings related to the annexation, inclusion, detachment, consolidation, merger, or dissolution of public bodies. SEC. 6 authorizes, confirms, validates, and declares legally effective all acts and proceedings related to the authorization, issuance, sale, execution, delivery, or exchange of bonds for any public purpose by public bodies. All bonds issued by public bodies are legally binding obligations, whether previously issued, awarded and sold, or authorized through various actions. The bonds authorized by a public body through an election and issued in accordance with that authorization are legally binding obligations. SEC. 7 of the act validates past acts and proceedings, limited by the California and United States Constitutions. It does not legalize any contested matters in legal proceedings within 30 days of the act's effective date. The act does not authorize or legalize any act, proceeding, or contract that has been previously determined to be illegal or void. Any challenge to the validity of actions taken for the formation, organization, or changes to public bodies must be filed within six months of this act's effective date. Otherwise, such actions will be deemed valid and legally binding. This act does not extend the time limit for legal action beyond what is currently allowed. The curr_chunk states that it allows for legal action beyond the statute of limitations. The act allows for legal action beyond the statute of limitations and specifies that any changes in public body boundaries must be filed promptly to be effective for assessment or taxation. It is deemed an urgency statute for the immediate preservation of public peace, health, or safety.
